mil3.4.4:0.3.eng: 4. Question on the Workings of Different Kamma

mil3.4.4:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, kena kāraṇena manussā na sabbe samakā, aññe appāyukā, aññe dīghāyukā, aññe bahvābādhā aññe appābādhā, aññe dubbaṇṇā, aññe vaṇṇavanto, aññe appesakkhā, aññe mahesakkhā, aññe appabhogā, aññe mahābhogā, aññe nīcakulīnā, aññe mahākulīnā, aññe duppaññā, aññe paññavanto”ti?
mil3.4.4:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, why is it that not all people are the same? Some people are short-lived, others long-lived, some have much affliction and others little affliction, some are ugly and others beautiful, some have little power and others great power, some have little wealth and others great wealth, some come from an inferior clan and others from a superior clan, some are foolish and others are wise.”

mil3.4.4:2.2.pli: “kissa pana, mahārāja, rukkhā na sabbe samakā, aññe ambilā, aññe lavaṇā, aññe tittakā, aññe kaṭukā, aññe kasāvā, aññe madhurā”ti?
mil3.4.4:2.2.eng: “Why then, your majesty, is it that not all trees are the same? Some are acidic, some are salty, some are bitter, some are pungent, some are astringent, and some are sweet?”

mil3.4.4:2.3.eng: “I think, venerable sir, that it is because of the difference in seeds.”

mil3.4.4:2.4.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, kammānaṃ nānākaraṇena manussā na sabbe samakā, aññe appāyukā, aññe dīghāyukā, aññe bahvābādhā, aññe appābādhā, aññe dubbaṇṇā, aññe vaṇṇavanto, aññe appesakkhā, aññe mahesakkhā, aññe appabhogā, aññe mahābhogā, aññe nīcakulīnā, aññe mahākulīnā, aññe duppaññā, aññe paññavanto.
mil3.4.4:2.4.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, it is because of the difference in kamma that not all people are the same. Some people are short-lived, others long-lived, some have much affliction and others little affliction, some are ugly and others beautiful, some have little power and others great power, some have little wealth and others great wealth, some come from an inferior clan and others from a superior clan, some are foolish and others are wise.

mil3.4.4:2.5.eng: And this too was said, your majesty, by the Blessed One:

mil3.4.4:2.6.pli: ‘kammassakā, māṇava, sattā kammadāyādā kammayonī kammabandhū kammappaṭisaraṇā, kammaṃ satte vibhajati yadidaṃ hīnappaṇītatāyā’”ti.
mil3.4.4:2.6.eng: ‘Young man, beings are the owners of their kamma, heirs to their kamma, born from their kamma, bound to their kamma, and protected by their kamma. Kamma divides beings into inferior and superior.’”

mil3.4.4:4.1.eng: Question on the Workings of Different Kamma fourth

mil3.4.5:0.3.eng: 5. Question on the Reason for Effort

mil3.4.5:1.3.pli: ‘kinti imaṃ dukkhaṃ nirujjheyya, aññañca dukkhaṃ nuppajjeyyāti.
mil3.4.5:1.3.eng: that, so that this suffering would cease and another suffering would not arise,

mil3.4.5:1.4.eng: that was the goal of your going forth.

mil3.4.5:1.5.pli: Kiṃ paṭikacceva vāyamitena, nanu sampatte kāle vāyamitabban”ti?
mil3.4.5:1.5.eng: Is it just because of previous effort? Should not one make an effort at the current time?”

mil3.4.5:1.7.pli: “sampatte kāle, mahārāja, vāyāmo akiccakaro bhavati, paṭikacceva vāyāmo kiccakaro bhavatī”ti.
mil3.4.5:1.7.eng: “Effort at the current time is not so useful, effort made previously is useful.”

mil3.4.5:2.2.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, yadā tvaṃ pipāsito bhaveyyāsi, tadā tvaṃ udapānaṃ khaṇāpeyyāsi, taḷākaṃ khaṇāpeyyāsi ‘pānīyaṃ pivissāmī’”ti?
mil3.4.5:2.2.eng: “What do you think, your majesty, when you become thirsty, would you then have a well or a dam dug and say ‘I will drink water’?”

mil3.4.5:2.4.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, sampatte kāle vāyāmo akiccakaro bhavati, paṭikacceva vāyāmo kiccakaro bhavatī”ti.
mil3.4.5:2.4.eng: “In the same way, effort at the current time is not so useful, effort made previously is useful.”

mil3.4.5:3.2.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, yadā tvaṃ bubhukkhito bhaveyyāsi, tadā tvaṃ khettaṃ kasāpeyyāsi, sāliṃ ropāpeyyāsi, dhaññaṃ atiharāpeyyāsi ‘bhattaṃ bhuñjissāmī’”ti?
mil3.4.5:3.2.eng: “What do you think, your majesty, when you become hungry, would you then have a field ploughed, plant rice, and have the grain brought in, and say ‘I will eat rice’?”

mil3.4.5:3.4.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, sampatte kāle vāyāmo akiccakaro bhavati, paṭikacceva vāyāmo kiccakaro bhavatī”ti.
mil3.4.5:3.4.eng: “In the same way, effort at the current time is not so useful, effort made previously is useful.”

mil3.4.5:4.2.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, yadā te saṅgāmo paccupaṭṭhito bhaveyya, tadā tvaṃ parikhaṃ khaṇāpeyyāsi, pākāraṃ kārāpeyyāsi, gopuraṃ kārāpeyyāsi, aṭṭālakaṃ kārāpeyyāsi, dhaññaṃ atiharāpeyyāsi, tadā tvaṃ hatthismiṃ sikkheyyāsi, assasmiṃ sikkheyyāsi, rathasmiṃ sikkheyyāsi, dhanusmiṃ sikkheyyāsi, tharusmiṃ sikkheyyāsī”ti?
mil3.4.5:4.2.eng: “What do you think, your majesty, when you are faced with a battle, would you then have a moat dug, a rampart, a gateway, and a watchtower constructed, and then train in the use of elephants, horses, chariots, bows and swords?”

mil3.4.5:4.4.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, sampatte kāle vāyāmo akiccakaro bhavati, paṭikacceva vāyāmo kiccakaro bhavati.
mil3.4.5:4.4.eng: “In the same way, effort at the current time is not so useful, effort made previously is useful.

mil3.4.5:4.5.eng: And this too was said, your majesty, by the Blessed One:

mil3.4.5:5.2.eng: what one knows is for one’s benefit;

mil3.4.5:5.3.eng: Not having thoughts like a wagon driver,

mil3.4.5:6.1.eng: As a wagon driver who has abandoned

mil3.4.5:6.4.eng: just broods with his axle broken,

mil3.4.5:7.3.eng: The lazy one coming face-to-face with death,

mil3.4.5:7.4.eng: just broods with his axle broken.’”

mil3.4.5:9.1.eng: Question on the Reason for Effort fifth

mil3.4.6:0.3.eng: 6. Question on the Nature of Heat in the Fires of Hell

mil3.4.6:1.3.pli: ‘pākatikaaggito nerayiko aggi mahābhitāpataro hoti, khuddakopi pāsāṇo pākatike aggimhi pakkhitto divasampi paccamāno na vilayaṃ gacchati, kūṭāgāramattopi pāsāṇo nerayikaggimhi pakkhitto khaṇena vilayaṃ gacchatī’ti, etaṃ vacanaṃ na saddahāmi, evañca pana vadetha ‘ye ca tattha uppannā sattā, te anekānipi vassasahassāni niraye paccamānā na vilayaṃ gacchantī’ti, tampi vacanaṃ na saddahāmī”ti.
mil3.4.6:1.3.eng: that the heat of hell has a far greater intensity than that of a normal fire, and that a small stone placed in a normal fire cooking all day would not be dissolved, whereas a stone the size of a gabled house placed in the fire of hell would be dissolved in a moment. I do not believe this assertion. And then you say that those various beings who have arisen in hell, cooking in that hell for thousands of years are not dissolved. That assertion too I do not believe.”

mil3.4.6:2.2.pli: “taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, yā tā santi makariniyopi susumāriniyopi kacchapiniyopi moriniyopi kapotiniyopi, kiṃ nu tā kakkhaḷāni pāsāṇāni sakkharāyo ca khādantī”ti?
mil3.4.6:2.2.eng: “What do you think, your majesty, do those female sharks, crocodiles, turtles, pea-hens, and pigeons eat hard stones and gravel?”

mil3.4.6:2.4.pli: “Kiṃ pana tāni tāsaṃ kucchiyaṃ koṭṭhabbhantaragatāni vilayaṃ gacchantī”ti?
mil3.4.6:2.4.eng: “But then when those have gone down into their abdomens and stomachs are they dissolved?”

mil3.4.6:2.6.pli: “Yo pana tāsaṃ kucchiyaṃ gabbho, sopi vilayaṃ gacchatī”ti?
mil3.4.6:2.6.eng: “But then is an embryo in their abdomens dissolved?”

mil3.4.6:2.9.eng: “I think, venerable sir, due to the workings of kamma it would not dissolve.”

mil3.4.6:2.10.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, kammādhikatena nerayikā sattā anekānipi vassasahassāni niraye paccamānā na vilayaṃ gacchanti.
mil3.4.6:2.10.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, those various beings in hell, cooking in that hell for thousands of years are not dissolved.

mil3.4.6:2.11.eng: And this too was said, your majesty, by the Blessed One:

mil3.4.6:2.12.pli: ‘so na tāva kālaṃ karoti, yāva na taṃ pāpakammaṃ byantīhotī’”ti.
mil3.4.6:2.12.eng: ‘One does not complete one’s time until there is an end to one’s evil kamma.’”

mil3.4.6:3.2.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, yā tā santi sīhiniyopi byagghiniyopi dīpiniyopi kukkuriniyopi, kiṃ nu tā kakkhaḷāni aṭṭhikāni maṃsāni khādantī”ti?
mil3.4.6:3.2.eng: “What do you think, your majesty, do female lions, tigers, panthers, and dogs eat hard bones and flesh?”

mil3.4.6:3.4.pli: “Kiṃ pana tāni tāsaṃ kucchiyaṃ koṭṭhabbhantaragatāni vilayaṃ gacchantī”ti?
mil3.4.6:3.4.eng: “But then when those have gone down into their abdomens and stomachs are they dissolved?”

mil3.4.6:3.6.pli: “Yo pana tāsaṃ kucchiyaṃ gabbho, sopi vilayaṃ gacchatī”ti?
mil3.4.6:3.6.eng: “But then is an embryo in their abdomens dissolved?”

mil3.4.6:3.9.eng: “I think, venerable sir, due to the workings of kamma it would not dissolve.”

mil3.4.6:3.10.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, kammādhikatena nerayikā sattā anekānipi vassasahassāni niraye paccamānā na vilayaṃ gacchantī”ti.
mil3.4.6:3.10.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, those various beings in hell, cooking in that hell for thousands of years are not dissolved.”

mil3.4.6:4.2.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, yā tā santi yonakasukhumāliniyopi khattiyasukhumāliniyopi brāhmaṇasukhumāliniyopi gahapatisukhumāliniyopi, kiṃ nu tā kakkhaḷāni khajjakāni maṃsāni khādantī”ti?
mil3.4.6:4.2.eng: “What do you think, your majesty, do those delicate Bactrian Greek women, noble women, brahmin women, and householder women eat hard cakes and meat?”

mil3.4.6:4.4.pli: “Kiṃ pana tāni tāsaṃ kucchiyaṃ koṭṭhabbhantaragatāni vilayaṃ gacchantī”ti?
mil3.4.6:4.4.eng: “But then when those have gone down into their abdomens and stomachs are they dissolved?”

mil3.4.6:4.6.pli: “Yo pana tāsaṃ kucchiyaṃ gabbho sopi vilayaṃ gacchatī”ti?
mil3.4.6:4.6.eng: “But then is an embryo in their abdomens dissolved?”

mil3.4.6:4.9.eng: “I think, venerable sir, due to the workings of kamma it would not dissolve.”

mil3.4.6:4.10.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, kammādhikatena nerayikā sattā anekānipi vassasahassāni niraye paccamānā na vilayaṃ gacchanti.
mil3.4.6:4.10.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, those various beings in hell, cooking in that hell for thousands of years are not dissolved.

mil3.4.6:4.11.eng: And this too was said, your majesty, by the Blessed One:

mil3.4.6:4.12.pli: ‘so na tāva kālaṃ karoti, yāva na taṃ pāpakammaṃ byantīhotī’”ti.
mil3.4.6:4.12.eng: ‘One does not complete one’s time until there is an end to one’s evil kamma.’”

mil3.4.6:6.1.eng: Question on the Nature of Heat in the Fires of Hell sixth

mil3.4.7:0.3.eng: 7. Question on the Bearing Up of the Earth

mil3.4.7:1.3.pli: ‘ayaṃ mahā pathavī udake patiṭṭhitā, udakaṃ vāte patiṭṭhitaṃ, vāto ākāse patiṭṭhito’ti, etampi vacanaṃ na saddahāmī”ti.
mil3.4.7:1.3.eng: this great earth is established on water, water is established on air, and air is established on space. I do not believe this assertion.”

mil3.4.7:1.4.pli: Thero dhammakarakena udakaṃ gahetvā rājānaṃ milindaṃ saññāpesi—
mil3.4.7:1.4.eng: The elder took some water in a water vessel and explained to King Milinda,

mil3.4.7:1.5.pli: “yathā, mahārāja, imaṃ udakaṃ vātena ādhāritaṃ, evaṃ tampi udakaṃ vātena ādhāritan”ti.
mil3.4.7:1.5.eng: “Just as, your majesty, this water is supported by the air, so too is that water supported by air.”

mil3.4.7:3.1.eng: Question on the Bearing Up of the Earth seventh

mil3.4.8:1.5.pli: “Sabbe bālaputhujjanā kho, mahārāja, ajjhattikabāhire āyatane abhinandanti abhivadanti ajjhosāya tiṭṭhanti, te tena sotena vuyhanti, na parimuccanti jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokena paridevena dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi ‘na parimuccanti dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi.
mil3.4.8:1.5.eng: “All those foolish ordinary people, your majesty, who delight in the internal and external sense bases, welcome them, remain clinging to them, and are carried away by that stream, are not free from birth, old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, anguish, and despair, they are not free from suffering, I say.

mil3.4.8:1.6.pli: Sutavā ca kho, mahārāja, ariyasāvako ajjhattikabāhire āyatane nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati, tassa taṃ anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato taṇhā nirujjhati, taṇhānirodhā upādānanirodho, upādānanirodhā bhavanirodho, bhavanirodhā jātinirodho, jātinirodhā jarāmaraṇaṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā nirujjhanti, evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hoti, evaṃ kho, mahārāja, nirodho nibbānan”ti.
mil3.4.8:1.6.eng: A well-taught noble disciple, your majesty, does not delight in the internal and external sense bases, nor welcome them, nor remain clinging to them. The one, not delighting in them, not welcoming them, not remaining clinging to them, is free from craving. From the cessation of craving, there is cessation of birth. From the cessation of birth, old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, grief, and despair cease, and thus there is the cessation of this whole mass of suffering. In this way, your majesty, cessation is nibbāna.”

mil3.4.8:3.1.eng: Question on Cessation and Nibbāna eighth

mil3.4.9:0.3.eng: 9. Question on the Attaining of Nibbāna

mil3.4.9:1.3.pli: “Na kho, mahārāja, sabbeva labhanti nibbānaṃ, api ca kho, mahārāja, yo sammā paṭipanno abhiññeyye dhamme abhijānāti, pariññeyye dhamme parijānāti, pahātabbe dhamme pajahati, bhāvetabbe dhamme bhāveti, sacchikātabbe dhamme sacchikaroti, so labhati nibbānan”ti.
mil3.4.9:1.3.eng: “Not everyone, your majesty, attains nibbāna. Whoever, practicing rightly, directly knows those things which should be directly known, completely comprehends those things that should be completely comprehended, abandons those things that should be abandoned, develops those things that should be developed, personally realizes those things that should be personally realized, that one attains nibbāna.”

mil3.4.9:3.1.eng: Question on the Attaining of Nibbāna ninth

mil3.5.1:0.3.eng: 1. Question on the Existence or Non-existence of the Buddha

mil3.5.1:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, have you seen the Buddha?”

mil3.5.1:1.4.eng: “Then, have your teachers seen the Buddha?”

mil3.5.1:1.6.eng: “Therefore, Venerable Nāgasena, there is no Buddha.”

mil3.5.1:1.7.pli: “Kiṃ pana, mahārāja, himavati ūhā nadī tayā diṭṭhā”ti?
mil3.5.1:1.7.eng: “Well then, your majesty, have you seen the River Ūhā in the Himalayas?”

mil3.5.1:1.9.eng: “Then has your father seen the River Ūhā?”

mil3.5.1:1.11.eng: “Because of this, your majesty, there is no River Ūhā.”

mil3.5.1:1.12.pli: “Atthi, bhante, kiñcāpi mayā ūhā nadī na diṭṭhā, pitarāpi me ūhā nadī na diṭṭhā, api ca atthi ūhā nadī”ti.
mil3.5.1:1.12.eng: “There is, venerable sir. Even though the River Ūhā has not been seen by me nor by my father, there is a River Ūhā.”

mil3.5.1:1.13.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, kiñcāpi mayā bhagavā na diṭṭho, ācariyehipi me bhagavā na diṭṭho, api ca atthi bhagavā”ti.
mil3.5.1:1.13.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, even though the Blessed One has not been seen by me nor by my teachers, there is a Blessed One.”

mil3.5.1:3.1.eng: Question on the Existence or Non-existence of the Buddha first

mil3.5.10:0.3.eng: 10. Question on Pointing Out the Buddha

mil3.5.10:1.3.eng: “Yes, your majesty, the Blessed One exists.”

mil3.5.10:1.4.pli: “Sakkā pana, bhante nāgasena, buddho nidassetuṃ idha vā idha vā”ti?
mil3.5.10:1.4.eng: “Is it then possible, venerable sir, to point to the Buddha as being either here or there?”

mil3.5.10:1.5.pli: “Parinibbuto, mahārāja, bhagavā anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā, na sakkā bhagavā nidassetuṃ ‘idha vā idha vā’”ti.
mil3.5.10:1.5.eng: “The Blessed One has passed away, your majesty, in the element of nibbāna without residue remaining, so it is not possible to point to the Blessed One as being either here or there.”

mil3.5.10:2.2.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, mahato aggikkhandhassa jalamānassa yā acci atthaṅgatā, sakkā sā acci dassetuṃ ‘idha vā idha vā’”ti?
mil3.5.10:2.2.eng: “What do you think, your majesty, when the flame of a great burning mass of fire has been extinguished, is it possible to point to that flame and say it remains here or there?”

mil3.5.10:2.3.pli: “Na hi, bhante, niruddhā sā acci appaññattiṃ gatā”ti.
mil3.5.10:2.3.eng: “Certainly not, venerable sir, for that flame has ceased and gone beyond description.”

mil3.5.10:2.4.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, bhagavā anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbuto atthaṅgato, na sakkā bhagavā nidassetuṃ ‘idha vā idha vā’ti, dhammakāyena pana kho, mahārāja, sakkā bhagavā nidassetuṃ.
mil3.5.10:2.4.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, the Blessed One has passed away in the element of nibbāna without residue remaining, so it is not possible to point to the Blessed One as being either here or there. However, your majesty, it is possible to point out the Blessed One through the body of Dhamma,

mil3.5.10:2.5.eng: for this Dhamma has been taught by the Blessed One.”

mil3.5.10:4.1.eng: Question on Pointing Out the Buddha tenth

mil3.5.2:0.3.eng: 2. Question on the Unsurpassed Nature of the Buddha

mil3.5.2:1.3.eng: “Yes, your majesty, the Blessed One is unsurpassed.”

mil3.5.2:1.4.eng: “How, Venerable Nāgasena, do you know the Buddha is unsurpassed if you haven’t seen him before?”

mil3.5.2:1.5.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, yehi adiṭṭhapubbo mahāsamuddo, jāneyyuṃ te, mahārāja, mahanto kho mahāsamuddo gambhīro appameyyo duppariyogāho, yatthimā pañca mahānadiyo satataṃ samitaṃ appenti, seyyathidaṃ—
mil3.5.2:1.5.eng: “What do you think, your majesty, would those who have not seen the great ocean before know that this great ocean is huge, deep, immeasurable, and unfathomable, such that as these five great rivers that flow into it constantly and continually, that is

mil3.5.2:1.6.pli: gaṅgā yamunā aciravatī sarabhū mahī, neva tassa ūnattaṃ vā pūrattaṃ vā paññāyatī”ti?
mil3.5.2:1.6.eng: the Gaṅgā, the Yamunā, the Aciravatī, the Sarabhū, and the Mahī, neither the depletion nor filling up of it is discerned?”

mil3.5.2:1.8.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, sāvake mahante parinibbute passitvā jānāmi ‘bhagavā anuttaro’”ti.
mil3.5.2:1.8.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, when I think of the great disciples who have attained final nibbāna, I know the Blessed One is unsurpassed.”

mil3.5.2:3.1.eng: Question on the Unsurpassed Nature of the Buddha second

mil3.5.3:0.3.eng: 3. Question on Knowing the Unsurpassed Nature of the Buddha

mil3.5.3:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, is it possible to know that the Buddha is unsurpassed?”

mil3.5.3:1.3.eng: “Yes, your majesty, it is possible to know that the Blessed One is unsurpassed.”

mil3.5.3:1.4.eng: “How, Venerable Nāgasena, is it possible to know that the Buddha is unsurpassed?”

mil3.5.3:1.5.pli: “Bhūtapubbaṃ, mahārāja, tissatthero nāma lekhācariyo ahosi, bahūni vassāni abbhatītāni kālaṅkatassa kathaṃ so ñāyatī”ti.
mil3.5.3:1.5.eng: “In the past, your majesty, an elder named Tissa was a teacher of writing and many years have passed since he passed away. How is it that he is still known?”

mil3.5.3:1.7.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, yo dhammaṃ passati, so bhagavantaṃ passati, dhammo hi, mahārāja, bhagavatā desito”ti.
mil3.5.3:1.7.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, whoever sees the Dhamma sees the Blessed One, for the Dhamma was taught by the Blessed One.”

mil3.5.3:3.1.eng: Question on Knowing the Unsurpassed Nature of the Buddha third

mil3.5.4:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, have you seen the Dhamma?”

mil3.5.4:1.3.pli: “Buddhanettiyā kho, mahārāja, buddhapaññattiyā yāvajīvaṃ sāvakehi vattitabban”ti.
mil3.5.4:1.3.eng: “Throughout their lives, your majesty, disciples should proceed with the Buddha as their guide, the Buddha as the one showing the way.”

mil3.5.4:3.1.eng: Question on Seeing the Dhamma fourth

mil3.5.5:0.3.eng: 5. Question on Reconnecting and Not Transmigrating

mil3.5.5:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, na ca saṅkamati paṭisandahati cā”ti?
mil3.5.5:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, is it so that one does not transmigrate and yet one reconnects?”

mil3.5.5:1.3.pli: “Āma, mahārāja, na ca saṅkamati paṭisandahati cā”ti.
mil3.5.5:1.3.eng: “Yes, your majesty, one does not transmigrate and yet one reconnects.”

mil3.5.5:1.4.pli: “Kathaṃ, bhante nāgasena, na ca saṅkamati paṭisandahati ca, opammaṃ karohī”ti?
mil3.5.5:1.4.eng: “How, Venerable Nāgasena, is it that one does not transmigrate and yet one reconnects? Please give me an analogy.”

mil3.5.5:1.5.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, kocideva puriso padīpato padīpaṃ padīpeyya, kiṃ nu kho so, mahārāja, padīpo padīpamhā saṅkanto”ti?
mil3.5.5:1.5.eng: “Just as, your majesty, if a person kindled one lamp from another would that lamp have transmigrated from the other lamp?”

mil3.5.5:1.7.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, na ca saṅkamati paṭisandahati cā”ti.
mil3.5.5:1.7.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, one does not transmigrate and yet one reconnects.”

mil3.5.5:2.2.pli: “Abhijānāsi nu tvaṃ, mahārāja, daharako santo silokācariyassa santike kiñci silokaṃ gahitan”ti?
mil3.5.5:2.2.eng: “Do you remember, your majesty, learning some verse from your teacher of verses?”

mil3.5.5:2.4.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, mahārāja, so siloko ācariyamhā saṅkanto”ti?
mil3.5.5:2.4.eng: “Then, your majesty, has that verse transmigrated from the teacher?”

mil3.5.5:2.6.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, na ca saṅkamati paṭisandahati cā”ti.
mil3.5.5:2.6.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, one does not transmigrate and yet one reconnects.”

mil3.5.5:4.1.eng: Question on Reconnecting and Not Transmigrating fifth

mil3.5.6:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, is an experiencer to be found?”

mil3.5.6:1.4.eng: “According to ultimate reality, an experiencer is not to be found.”

mil3.5.7:0.3.eng: 7. Question on Transmigrating to Another Body

mil3.5.7:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, atthi koci satto yo imamhā kāyā aññaṃ kāyaṃ saṅkamatī”ti?
mil3.5.7:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, is there any being at all that transmigrates from this body to another body?”

mil3.5.7:1.4.pli: “Yadi, bhante nāgasena, imamhā kāyā aññaṃ kāyaṃ saṅkamanto natthi, nanu mutto bhavissati pāpakehi kammehī”ti?
mil3.5.7:1.4.eng: “If, venerable sir, there is no transmigrating from this body to another body, is it not then that one would be freed from evil actions?”

mil3.5.7:1.5.pli: “Āma, mahārāja, yadi na paṭisandaheyya, mutto bhavissati pāpakehi kammehīti, yasmā ca kho, mahārāja, paṭisandahati, tasmā na parimutto pāpakehi kammehī”ti.
mil3.5.7:1.5.eng: “Yes, your majesty, if it would not reconnect, then one would be freed from evil actions. But because, your majesty, it does reconnect, one therefore is not freed from evil actions.”

mil3.5.7:2.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, kocideva puriso aññatarassa purisassa ambaṃ avahareyya, kiṃ so daṇḍappatto bhaveyyā”ti?
mil3.5.7:2.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, some person or other might steal another person’s mangos, would that man deserve punishment?”

mil3.5.7:2.3.eng: “Yes, venerable sir, he would deserve punishment.”

mil3.5.7:2.4.pli: “Na kho so, mahārāja, tāni ambāni avahari, yāni tena ropitāni, kasmā daṇḍappatto bhaveyyā”ti?
mil3.5.7:2.4.eng: “But, your majesty, those mangos that were taken are not the same as those that were planted, why would he deserve punishment?”

mil3.5.7:2.5.pli: “Tāni, bhante, ambāni nissāya jātāni, tasmā daṇḍappatto bhaveyyā”ti.
mil3.5.7:2.5.eng: “Those mangos, venerable sir, arose dependent on the others, therefore he would deserve punishment.”

mil3.5.7:2.6.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, iminā nāmarūpena kammaṃ karoti sobhanaṃ vā asobhanaṃ vā, tena kammena aññaṃ nāmarūpaṃ paṭisandahati, tasmā na parimutto pāpakehi kammehī”ti.
mil3.5.7:2.6.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, with this name-and-form one performs a lovely or an evil action, and by this action another name-and-form reconnects. Therefore, one is not freed from evil actions.”

mil3.5.7:4.1.eng: Question on Transmigrating to Another Body seventh

mil3.5.8:0.3.eng: 8. Question on the Existence of the Fruits of Actions

mil3.5.8:1.2.pli: “bhante nāgasena, iminā nāmarūpena kammaṃ kataṃ kusalaṃ vā akusalaṃ vā, kuhiṃ tāni kammāni tiṭṭhantī”ti?
mil3.5.8:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, for a wholesome or unwholesome action done by this name-and-form, where do those actions remain?”

mil3.5.8:1.3.pli: “Anubandheyyuṃ kho, mahārāja, tāni kammāni chāyāva anapāyinī”ti.
mil3.5.8:1.3.eng: “Those actions would follow one, your majesty, like a shadow that never leaves.”

mil3.5.8:1.4.pli: “Sakkā pana, bhante, tāni kammāni dassetuṃ ‘idha vā idha vā tāni kammāni tiṭṭhantī’”ti?
mil3.5.8:1.4.eng: “Is it then possible, venerable sir, to point to those actions and say they remain here or there?”

mil3.5.8:1.5.pli: “Na sakkā, mahārāja, tāni kammāni dassetuṃ ‘idha vā idha vā tāni kammāni tiṭṭhantī’”ti.
mil3.5.8:1.5.eng: “It is not possible, your majesty, to point to those actions and say they remain here or there.”

mil3.5.8:2.2.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, yānimāni rukkhāni anibbattaphalāni, sakkā tesaṃ phalāni dassetuṃ ‘idha vā idha vā tāni phalāni tiṭṭhantī’”ti.
mil3.5.8:2.2.eng: “What do you think, your majesty, for those trees where the fruit has not yet arisen, is it possible to point to those fruits and say those fruits remain here or there?”

mil3.5.8:2.4.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, abbocchinnāya santatiyā na sakkā tāni kammāni dassetuṃ ‘idha vā idha vā tāni kammāni tiṭṭhantī’”ti.
mil3.5.8:2.4.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, as long as the continuity of life is not cut off, it is not possible to point to those actions and say they remain here or there.”

mil3.5.8:4.1.eng: Question on the Existence of the Fruits of Actions eighth

mil3.5.9:1.2.eng: “Venerable Nāgasena, does one who re-arises know, ‘I will re-arise’?”

mil3.5.9:1.3.eng: “Yes, your majesty, one who re-arises knows, ‘I will re-arise’.”

mil3.5.9:2.2.pli: “Yathā, mahārāja, kassako gahapatiko bījāni pathaviyaṃ nikkhipitvā sammā deve vassante jānāti ‘dhaññaṃ nibbattissatī’”ti?
mil3.5.9:2.2.eng: “Just as, your majesty, when a householder farmer plants seeds in the ground and it rains well, does he know that grain will grow?”

mil3.5.9:2.4.pli: “Evameva kho, mahārāja, yo uppajjati, jānāti so ‘uppajjissāmī’”ti.
mil3.5.9:2.4.eng: “In the same way, your majesty, one who re-arises knows, ‘I will re-arise’.”
